contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{About|insect anatomy|halteres as used in ancient sports|Halteres (ancient Greece)}} [[File:Crane fly halteres.jpg|thumb|320px|right|[[Crane fly]], with a pair of halteres visible behind the wings as appendages, about as long as the animal's [[antenna (biology)|antennae]], with knobs on the end]] '''''Halteres''''' ({{IPAc-en|h|æ|l|ˈ|t|ɪər|iː|z}}; singular '''''halter''''' or '''''haltere''''') are small knobbed structures modified from the hind wings (or front wings in the case of [[Strepsiptera]]) in some two-winged [[insect]]s. They are flapped rapidly and function as [[gyroscope]]s, informing the insect about rotation of the body during flight.<ref name=klowden/> The word 'halter' comes from Greek ἁλτήρ, a double knobbed device used in Ancient Greece by athletes during training in jumping. In Diptera, the formation of the haltere during [[metamorphosis]] is dependent on the [[homeotic gene]] [[Ultrabithorax]] (Ubx). If this gene is experimentally deactivated, the haltere will develop into a fully developed wing.<ref name=klowden>Klowden, M. J. (2007). ''Physiological systems in insects''. Elsevier/Academic Press. pp. 497-499.</ref> This is an excellent illustration of an important mechanism of a simple homeotic gene change can result in a radically different [[phenotype]]. Halteres flap up and down as the wings do and operate as [[vibrating structure gyroscope]]s. Every vibrating object tends to maintain its plane of vibration if its support is rotated, a result of [[Newton's laws of motion|Newton's first law]]. If the body of the insect changes direction in flight or rotates about its axis, the vibrating halteres thus exert a force on the body. The insect detects this force with [[Sensory system|sensory organs]] known as [[campaniform sensilla]] located at the base of the halteres. The planes of vibration of the two halteres are [[Orthogonality|orthogonal]] to each other, each forming an angle of about 45 degrees with the axis of the insect; this increases the amount of information gained from the halteres. Halteres thus act as a [[Balance (ability)|balancing]] and [[guidance system]], helping these insects to perform their fast [[aerobatics]]. In addition to providing rapid feedback to the muscles steering the wings, they also play an important role in stabilizing the head during flight. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/3338943/QED-These-tiny-flying-machines-really-are-magnificent.html QED: These tiny flying machines really are magnificent], ''The Telegraph'', 9 February 2005 * [http://www.fva-bw.de/forschung/bu/bodenschluessel/img/orginf_halteren.jpg Photo of a haltere of a mosquito (Nematocera)] [[Category:Insect anatomy]]
